Body: What's the best evidence against a position like that expounded by e.g. Bob Port (or Ken Lodge, for you UK-based phon*ists), which essentially states that phonology (or whatever you want to call the cognitive/internal aspect of the acoustic/auditory/articulatory bits of language) is essentially non-segmental, and that segmental phenomena only emerge post-literacy training?
Title: What evidence is there against "nonsegmental" phonology?

OwnerUser.AboutMe: Former cognitive scientist/phonological modeller, now working in industry. Interested in the respective roles of vertical and horizontal language transmission in language change, and more generally of diachrony as a source of synchronic phonological patterning.
